Given By Glee Club, Band
Pictures on page 2

trld Dance will be presented toevening at the Maryland

Stickmen Battle Virginia Here
In Season Opener Tomorrow;
Cavaliers Guided By Fewster
The 1954 edition of the Johns
Hopkins lacrosse team opens its
season tomorrow afternoon playing host to the University of
Virginia on Homewood Field.
Game time is 2:30 p.m.

"Potpourri Pour Faire Rire"
will be presented by the Quartet,
consisting of Gary Nelson, Charles
Cook, Joseph Donahue and James
Hall. Accompanist Dick Kapp
will offer a few selected solo numbers.
Band Plays Cole Porter Selections
The Concert Band will number
among its selections songs by Cole
Porter and the Hopkins March,
by Gebelein.

After-Class Honor
By JOHN MAYO-WELLS

h This is the fourth of a series of articles written with the
'aPeration of John Beever, Honor Commission Chairman, on
n-academic honor violations.
II, In past issues Dick Cohn, IFB president, and Dave Jennings,
., 11,C chairman, have expressed their views on this topic. Cohn
"s
tt erted that honor should come from the moral responsibility
1, the individual, and Jennings favored establishment of a Dorm
'al Commission. In the following article, Alan Birtch, Student
414cil president, presents his position.
"Because of the strengthening of the IFB and the increased
417Pe of the DSRC, we find these two groups have taken particular
Ice of the problem. A third organization has also taken note of
e Problem and it is in this group, the Honor Commission, that
4 reel our solution lies. The Honor Commission shall 'uphold
Promote the traditions of the ... Honor System;... and
411 investigate and set upon all violations of the Honor Code.'
is the present purpose of the commission as set forth in
constitution.
ih No group sets up a standard of conduct without realizing that
1t4e will be a few who will not or can not live up to this
4411dard. It is a foolish organization, which, realizing this, does
make plans for the treatment of these few—whether "Big
tkk" be hollered or not.

Z

j

.4Eiffic 58th Year

Jay mentor and current Cavalier
coach will clash tomorrow at
Homewood Field at 2 p.m.

Virginia's Cavaliers, coached
by Wilson Fewster, will be rebounding from a humiliating 18-7
defeat at the hands of the University of Maryland Terps last
Saturday at Charlottesville.
•
Key man in the Cavalier's defensive picture and big question
mark in tomorrow's game is
goalie G. P.(Bo) Moore, who was
placed on the second string of the
All-American team last year.

June Week Costs Up;
Discount For Seniors
$13.75, less one dollar if they are
purchased before May 15.
Last year tickets had to be
bought before May 15 to get the
discount. This year the discount
strip tickets will be sold up until
June 1. This year's prices represent an increase of fifty cents for
seniors and more than a dollar for
underclassmen.

The prices for the separate
events of June Week were an;
nounced by Walpert as follows:
for the prom, $5.50, for the Moonlight Cruise, $2.00, and for the
"We'll cover all band expenses,
Sports Dance, $3.80. These affairs
. that's all," Walpert stated.
are open to underclassmen and but
they may buy a strip ticket for Class dues will make up the difall three for $10.15, a saving of ference.
$1.15.

5 will be $4.00, bringing their
ticket total, if bought separately,

Notice

Frosh Shafted

Moore finished the 1953 season
with 162 saves for a 70 per cent
average at the nets.
Veterans Pace Squad
Hopkins mentor Fred Smith
scrimmaged his charges against
Hobart and Duke University during the past week in preparation
for tomorrow's assault against
Moore's nets. Smith has built his
undermanned squad around veterans Lou Ruland, goalie; Buzzy
Williams and Bob Fleishman, defense; Dick Steele and Ray Santamaria, midfield; and John Boynton, at close attack.
Tomorrow's battle will be a
homecoming game for Fewster,
the Virginia coach, and the entire
Cavalier starting lineup. Goalie
Moore, Defensemen Clayton Smith
and Lee Bortner, and Midfielder
Tom Beall are graduates of McDonough in Baltimore. Don Nichols and Lou Hargrave are graduates of Severn; Fred Whitridge,
of Gilman; Jimmy Grieves, of St.
Paul's; Eddy Vest, of Friends;
and Granny Swope, of Boy's Latin.
Fewster Returns
Fewster played lacrosse at Hopkins in '47, '48, and'50 and came
back to coach the sport in 1952
(Continued on Page 3)

Petitions for the Student Council and class elections must be
submitted by 5 p.m., April 6. Petitions for all SC and the four class
offices—president, vice-president,
secretary, and treasurer, require
signatures of ten per cent of the
applicant's class; petitions for the
SC presidency require signatures
of five per cent of the student
body, according to Alan Birtch,
SC president.

e Problem and it is in this group, the Honor Commission, that
4 reel our solution lies. The Honor Commission shall 'uphold
Promote the traditions of the ... Honor System;... and
411 investigate and set upon all violations of the Honor Code.'
is the present purpose of the commission as set forth in
constitution.
ih No group sets up a standard of conduct without realizing that
1t4e will be a few who will not or can not live up to this
4411dard. It is a foolish organization, which, realizing this, does

tkk" be hollered or not.
